awd_titl_txt: CRII: CIF:  New Directions in Learning from Data with Faulty Correspondence
awd_abstract_narration:
Contemporary data acquisition and analysis frequently involves the integration of multiple pieces of information about a common set of entities into a single comprehensive data set. In the absence of unique identifiers, merging corresponding fragments of data can be demanding and error-prone. This challenge is encountered in various settings covering applications in engineering such as sensor networks as well as in the work of government data analytics. In this project, it is explored to what extent functional relationships between different data sets can be leveraged to resolve potential ambiguities in the process of data integration. This question is also relevant to data confidentiality in situations in which an adversary tries to disclose sensitive information from anonymized data by using auxiliary data sources.

The objective of the project is the development and statistical analysis of computationally feasible methods to safeguard downstream statistical analysis against errors in data linkage and to restore missing or faulty correspondences. In this context, linear regression in the presence of an unknown permutation is of central interest. One specific direction of research is the use of prior knowledge about the underlying permutation as commonly available in applications with the goal to sidestep computational barriers and to reduce the occurrent of ill-posed problems in statistical estimation. Emphasis will be placed on the characterization of the fundamental limits of recovery. Making advances in this regard will entail the use of tools from various areas including the theory of assignment problems, nonlinear optimization, high-dimensional and robust statistical inference, and random matrix theory. Results of the conducted research can potentially impact related problems such as regression under unknown linear transform, including blind deconvolution, and inference for permutations, as found in ranking, seriation, or graph matching.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
Integrating micro-level data resulting from multiple sources or asynchronous data collection protocols poses a significant challenge in modern engineering and data science applications. Specifically, the research conducted during the work on this project has focused on two settings: Record Linkage and Unlabeled Sensing. (1) Record Linkage denotes the process of record-by-record merging of multiple data sets pertaining to a common set of entities in the presence of uncertainty about matching records, (2) Unlabeled Sensing refers to data acquisition in the (partial) absence of the locations of the measurements. Both sub-areas are interdisciplinary and involve contributions from computer science, mathematics, signal processing, and engineering.

Intellectual Merit:  Over the duration of the project, the project team consisting of the PI, one doctoral student, and an unfunded collaborator have co-authored five peer-reviewed journal publications and one peer-reviewed conference publication in top venues in the aforementioned disciplines. A sixth journal publication is pending. These publications address a series of problems of importance in the subject areas, and have propelled further research by the PI and other researchers. Citation analysis further corroborates the significance and impact of the conducted work. Research results were disseminated to a broader audience at a mini-symposium at the SIAM Conference on the Mathematics of Data Science, the American Association for Public Opinion Research Conference, and several other venues of high visbility in the statistics community on the topic of record linkage.

Broader Impacts: The advances made during the work on this project have applications in robotics, signal processing, computer vision, and record linkage, among others, and thus have potential in stimulating developments in technology and society. In particular, research outcomes were disseminated to the United States Census Bureau to facilitate record linkage involving administrative data. The project has also contributed to graduate education: one doctoral student funded by this project completed their dissertation and aspects of the project were used for curricular development.      


Last Modified: 03/13/2023
Modified by: Martin Slawski
